definition: Major structural body parts excluding the head, encompassing the trunk and appendages that enable movement and posture

positive_examples: She stretched her arms above her head and twisted her torso to the left
The dancer's graceful neck movements complemented her fluid arm gestures
He felt a sharp pain in his shoulder blade near his spine
The swimmer's powerful stroke engaged her entire torso and limbs
She wrapped her arms around her waist and hunched her shoulders
The yoga pose required balancing on one leg while extending the other
negative_examples: Her face lit up with a bright smile
The child's eyes sparkled with curiosity
He nodded his head in agreement
She had beautiful long hair cascading down
The dentist examined his teeth and gums
Her brain processed the complex information quickly
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Head, Face, Brain, Eye, Hair

opposite_reasoning: Head is the optimal opposite for TorsoAndLimbs because: (1) The definition explicitly excludes the head ('Major structural body parts excluding the head'), making this a definitional complement; (2) Together they form a complete, non-overlapping partition of major body structure; (3) High availability in both WordNet and SUMO ontologies; (4) Creates a meaningful anatomical axis for Fisher-LDA separation. While this opposition has limited direct AI safety utility, it provides the strongest semantic contrast for the anatomical domain and enables clear concept boundaries. The Head concept should definitely be added to the same layer if not already present.
